text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review of
the new black heart rebellion album har
Nev oh these guys are a Belgian rock
outfit as far as I can tell this is
their sophomore full-length LP the thing
is about forty minutes and these forty
minutes are spread across eight
different tracks and it's a pretty
intriguing release with a combination of
genres such as post rock psychedelic
rock folk music maybe a little bit of
post metal drone doom mmm I could
definitely tell that these guys
appreciate maybe a little bit of the
Mogwai maybe a little bit of the swans
and even though this band's stylistic
genre influences are very apparent they
don't always necessarily come together
in in a really obvious way which is
great like the song crawling and eating
dust which starts off with just this
dark sickening and eerie ominous drum
circle there are these chilling chorus
vocals that pop up over the drum circle
and as the song progresses some droning
guitar and bass comes in and it is heavy
and resonant these guys are really great
at using sound and texture to just
create drama create darkness after this
part in the song these spoken-word
vocals come in but they've got this sort
of just whisper quiet sort of sinister
character to them this song and many
others on here just get more and more
intense as they go on the primal drone
on this track eventually goes toward
this huge
sike rock climax wailing guitars heavy
bass the vocals turn from whispering to
just all-out aggression and they do all
of us without losing the occult vibe
that the song started off with like I
said other tracks kind of work with this
same sort of arc the same sort of
progression but the band does it with
different flavours of music like the
song a NAR dot which I don't know if I'm
pronouncing correctly but it too gets
more in
as it goes on but it kicks things off
with sort of a 70s heavy metal style to
it kind of like Black Sabbath when heavy
metal still had a really prominent
bluesy hardrock influence and even
though they definitely go a little heavy
metal on this track they still managed
to make the song just very slow dramatic
jeroni deadpan vocals on this thing
pots and pans percussion bunched up with
the drums to again give it that kind of
prime evil vibe
I love the passionate group vocals at
the end of this track two moments like
this really sort of stick with me even
though these guys aren't exactly a
course oriented band the production the
experimentation the adventure the sounds
they're all there
the variety on this LP continues with
tracks like gold and myrrh which opens
up with these chords that feel as if
they're a little inspired by Spanish
guitar music maybe a little bit of
flamenco the downside to this particular
track though is that some of the noisy
and psychedelic builds that the band
goes on are a little more interesting
than others this one particularly
nothing really about it sticks out of me
if anything it kind of reminds me of a
cut from that new god speed album that
came out last year and there are other
tracks on here like abraham which are a
great start to the album add a lot of
color to this LP but they're a lot
shorter than some of the other tracks on
here and while it's not bad to have a
shorter track on this album
theoretically it's not like the band is
able to kind of tie things up
efficiently give some closure or write a
song that feels concise within a three
or four minute time span instead some of
these relatively shorter songs can end
up feeling like they could have gone
somewhere as interesting as some of the
other tracks still overall there's way
more highlights on this album than does
even though I wasn't completely in love
with it maybe my favorite song the
entire LP being animal esque
which has a twisted song structure the
guitars on this track just jangle
epically and I love the the angry ass
vocals on this song just how fierce they
come across dust dust the explosive
ending on this thing too is awesome this
album and in this track in particular
it's just monolithic it shoots four
monolithic much of the time and I will
say that it succeeds the black heart
rebellion has a
huge sound they definitely have a nice
recording on this album and they know
what to do with it instrumentally this
album is so heavy and yet it can at
times be sort of eerie or quaint like at
the start of the last track which has
some interesting banjo on it I do feel
like the cell P could be a little bit
more cohesive in terms of a narrative or
a story or an arc it seems like every
song on here is sort of its own little
nook or cranny or niche instead of the
entire album sort of having an
interesting progression to it and even
though I did end up with some tracks
paling in comparison to others still
this is a really solid set of tracks and
I feel like this band is doing some
really interesting stuff on this LP but
they're just like this close to doing
something whoa hopefully that ends up
being the case on their next release I'm
feeling a decent too strong seven on
this thing if you've given it a listen
what did you think of it did you love it
did you hate it why what do you think I
should review next and yeah that's it
Blackheart rebellion forever
